definition: Chief of Staff to the Supreme Allied Commander. The planning organization that developed the initial invasion plans before SHAEF was established.
Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force. The command structure led by General Eisenhower that oversaw Operation Overlord.
The Allied deception operation that convinced Germany the main invasion would target Pas-de-Calais rather than Normandy.
Portable artificial harbors developed by the British to supply forces over the Normandy beaches before a port could be captured.
The extensive system of German coastal fortifications stretching from Norway to Spain, designed to repel an Allied invasion.
Duplex Drive tanks - Sherman tanks fitted with flotation screens that allowed them to swim ashore and provide close fire support.
Landing Craft, Vehicle, Personnel. The iconic flat-bottomed boats that carried troops from ships to the invasion beaches.
Elite paratroopers who jumped ahead of the main force to mark drop zones with lights and radar beacons.
Engineless aircraft towed by powered planes and released to land troops, vehicles, and equipment silently behind enemy lines.
A designated area where paratroopers and their equipment were to land after jumping from aircraft.
The Norman hedgerow countryside of small fields bordered by dense hedges and sunken lanes, which heavily favored defensive fighting.
The codename for the Allied invasion of Normandy and the larger battle for the region in summer 1944.
The codename for the naval assault phase of D-Day, including the channel crossing and beach landings.
The designated time for the start of operations on D-Day. Different beaches had different H-Hours based on tidal conditions.
Networks of French civilians who fought against German occupation through sabotage, intelligence gathering, and armed action.
